titleStmt.title: Description of University of Pennsylvania Ms. Codex 2032: Prieres de la messe.

notesStmt.note: Title from title page and caption title (f. 1r, 3r); spine title L'ord[re] de la messe.

1. f.3r-4r: [Introductory prayer] -- 2. f.4v-8v: Au Confiteor -- 3. f.8v-10v: Au Kyrie -- 4. f.11r-12r: Au Gloria -- 5. f.12v-14r: A l'Evangile -- 6. f.14v-17v: Au Credo -- 7. f.18r-22v: A l'Offertoire -- 8. f.23r-26r: Au Lavabo -- 9. f.26v-28r: Au Sanctus -- 10: f.28v-43v: Au Canon -- 11. f.44r-52v: Au Pater -- 12. f.53r-56r: A la Communion -- 13. f.56v-60r: Au dernier Evangile.

msIdentifier.repository: Kislak Center for Special Collections, Rare Books and Manuscripts

msContents.summary: Book of prayers for an aristocratic lay reader's private use during the Mass, decorated with watercolor and gold, with iconography drawn primarily from the Passion cycle used for the Hours of the Cross.
msContents.textLang: French, with a few words in Latin referring to parts of the Mass

respStmt.persName: Augustus Frederick, Prince, Duke of Sussex, 1773-1843

supportDesc.extent: 60 leaves : 167 x 100 (124 x 70) mm bound to 170 x 110 mm
supportDesc.foliation: Paper, iii + 60 + iii; modern foliation in pencil, lower right recto, [i-iii, 1-60, i-iii].

layoutDesc.layout: Written in 12 long lines; box-ruled in lead; octavo format.

scriptDesc.scriptNote: Written in italic script by royal calligrapher Jean Pierre Rousselet.

binding.p: 18th-century ox-blood morocco, gilt-stamped with coats of arms on covers (ducal coronet above a double coat of arms enclosed by a cordon, in front of crossed maces) and flowers in corners; gilt spine with title L'ord de la messe; leather pastedowns inside covers with gilt-stamped floral borders; fabric-backed marbled endpapers; two ribbon bookmarks; gilt edges.

origin.p: Written in France for an aristocratic owner between 1677 and 1736 (dates of Rousselet's activity).

history.provenance: Formerly owned by Prince Augustus Frederick, Duke of Sussex, son of George III (armorial bookplate inside upper cover), his number VI. H.h.13 (bookplate, f. i recto).
Sold by Second Story Books (Washington, DC, and Rockville, Maryland), 2019.
Offered at auction at Messrs. Evans (London) in the collection of the late Duke of Sussex, 31 July-3 August 1844, lot 273.
